metadata.title: LSPR-driven upconversion enhancement and photocatalytic H2 evolution for Er-Yb_TiO2/MoO3-x nano-semiconductor heterostructure

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Ceramics International
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/ceramint
LSPR-driven upconversion enhancement and photocatalytic H2 evolution for Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x nano-semiconductor heterostructure
Jingyu Shanga,b, Xuesong Xua,∗, Kuichao Liub, Yanan Baob, Yangyangb, Ming Hec,∗∗
a School of Science, Dalian Maritime University, 116026, China b Key Laboratory of Photosensitive Materials and Device of Liaoning Province, Key Laboratory of New Energy and Rare Earth Resource Utilization of State Ethnic Affairs Commission, School of Physics and Materials Engineering, Dalian Minzu University, Dalian, 116600, China c Department of Physics, College of Science, Dalian Jiaotong University, Dalian, 116028, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH Upconversion luminescence Charge carriers channel Ammonia borane H2 producing
A B S T R A C T
Localized surface plasmon resonances (LSPR) are widely employed for improving the upconversion luminescence (UCL) and photocatalysis. Here, we prepare a nano-semiconductor heterostructure (NSH) consisting of ErYb:TiO2 nanosheets (NTs) integrated with plasmonic MoO3-x NTs in a two-step solvothermal processes. The LSPR of MoO3-x amplifies and transfers the near-infrared (NIR) energy to the neighboring Er-Yb:TiO2 UC system, leading to a 182-fold increase in green emissions. Moreover, the LSPR effect extends the absorption range of the Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH from the visible to the NIR region. The interface of the Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH acts as a charge carrier channel to separate the plasmon-induced electrons and holes effectively. We perform H2 production experiments of Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH from ammonia borane (BH3NH3). Upon the excitation of a 980 nm laser, the H2 production of the Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH is 1.5 times and 61 times higher than that of the MoO3-x NTs and BH3NH3. In addition, the H2 yield is 2.5 times and 52 times higher than that of the MoO3-x NTs and BH3NH3 under the irradiation of simulated sunlight (AM 1.5), demonstrating the superior photocatalytic properties of the Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Rare-earth (RE) doped materials are used extensively for various applications such as temperature sensing and biological imaging [1–3]. Unfortunately, their low upconversion luminescence (UCL) efficiency represents a problem owing to nonradiative relaxation in a conventional UC system [4], particularly for metal oxide host materials, which have relatively high phonon energy [5]. Much effort has been focused on improving the UCL. Noble metal nanoparticles can be fabricated on UC materials to boost the UCL due to the localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) effect [6–8]. Nevertheless, the application of noble metal plasmonic nanoparticles is limited because of limited resources and high cost. Recently, non-stoichiometric heavily doped semiconductors such as WO3-x, Cu2-xS, and MoO3-x have been used by researchers because of the simple synthesis process [4,9–12], wide LPSR absorption band, and tunable optical properties [13,14]. The LSPR excitation of these semiconductors is due to the collective vibration of excess carriers resulting from lattice defects. LSPR excitation produces a strong electromagnetic field and amplifies incident photon energy.
When the UCL material is fabricated with plasmonic semiconductors to form a heterostructure, the energy can be transferred to the adjacent UCL material and increase its UCL efficiency.
Photocatalytic H2 production is an excellent approach to address the energy crisis [15–17]. Nonetheless, the high charge carrier recombination rate is a problem when using semiconductor photocatalysts [18]. Also, the finite absorption range of photocatalysts limits their practical application. To solve these problems, numerous studies have been conducted on the modification of photocatalysts [19,20]. In recent years, semiconductor photocatalysts loaded with noble metal nanoparticles is brought into focus by virtue of LSPR effect [21]. Our previous study has demonstrated that the loading of Ag nanoparticles onto Znln2S4/TiO2 resulted in excellent H2 production due to the SPRcoupling effect under the irradiation of simulated sunlight; this approach represents a solution to the problem of the high carrier recombination rate [22]. However, the absorption band for noble metal nanoparticles is narrow, which limits the full usage of sunlight. Therefore, it is necessary to find a candidate material to solve this problem.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ceramint.2019.05.203 Received 17 April 2019; Received in revised form 2 May 2019; Accepted 20 May 2019
∗ Corresponding author. ∗∗ Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: xuxuesong@dlmu.edu.cn (X. Xu), heming@djtu.edu.cn (M. He).
Ceramics International 45 (2019) 16625–16630
Available online 21 May 2019 0272-8842/ © 2019 Elsevier Ltd and Techna Group S.r.l. All rights reserved.
T
In this study, we design a Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x nano-semiconductor heterostructure (NSH), which exhibits very high UCL under the excitation of a 980 nm laser. Additionally, MoO3-x nanosheets (NTs) trap incident light in a wide wavelength range and generate plasmonic “hot electrons”, which are transferred to the Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs by an hot electron injection process through a charge carrier channel, namely the interfaces formed between the Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs and the MoO3-x NTs for photocatalytic reaction. The Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSHs exhibit significantly higher photocatalytic H2 production than the MoO3-x NTs. The proposed method provides an efficient strategy for LSPR-driven UCL improvement and wide-spectrum responsive H2 production with high performance.

sections.heading: 2.1. Synthesis of the Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs
sections.text: Hydrochloric acid (HCl) (5 mL) was poured into ethanol (C2H5OH) (8mL) dissolved with 5.6mg of Er(Cl)3·6H2O and 28.5mg of Yb (Cl)3·6H2O. Then n-butyl titanate (Ti(OBu)4) (5mL) was added to the mixture dropwise under continuous stirring to form a transparent solution. The molar ratios were 0.1:0.5:100 for Er3+:Yb3+:Ti4+. Subsequently, 0.8 mL of hydrofluoric acid (HF) was introduced as a surface active agent to form a sheet. The reason for the addition of HCl was to prevent the rapid hydrolysis of Ti(OBu)4. Finally, the mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and the reaction occurred for 12 h at 433 K to obtain the Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of the MoO3-x NTs
sections.text: In a conventional process, 60mg of molybdenum powder was dispersed into C2H6O while stirring for 30min. After that, 0.94mL of H2O2 was added dropwise to the mixture and stirring continued for 30min. The as-prepared mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave where it remained at a temperature of 413 K for 12 h. The MoO3-x NTs were successfully synthesized.

sections.heading: 2.3. Synthesis of the Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH
sections.text: The Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs were uniformly dispersed in 25mL of C2H5OH using an ultrasonic process for 3 h. Next, 60mg of molybdenum powder was added to the suspension and stirred for 30min. Afterward, 0.94mL of perhydrol (H2O2) was added dropwise to the solution and stirred until it turned yellow. The mixture was transferred into the Teflon-lined autoclave and the reaction occurred for 12 h at 413 K to obtain the ErYb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH.

sections.heading: 2.4. Photocurrent measurement
sections.text: For the electrochromic experiments, the as-prepared samples of ErYb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH and MoO3-x NTs were immersed in 0.2mol/L of Na2SO4 solution and irradiated with a 300-W Xe lamp (NBET, HSXF300). The initial voltage was −0.2 V and the shutter opened every 10 s.

sections.heading: 2.5. H2 evolution experiments
sections.text: In a typical process, 4 mL of deionized water was poured into a quartz reactor loaded with 2mg of Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH. An aqueous solution of ammonia borane (BH3NH3) (0.8 mL, 1mg/mL) was added to the mixture after exhausting the air with the argon gas for 10min. The reaction occurred for 1 h under the irradiation of a 980 nm laser or simulated sunlight. The produced gas was collected every 15min. Control experiments were conducted with the MoO3-x NTs and BH3NH3.

sections.heading: 2.6. Materials characterization
sections.text: The nanostructures of the samples were characterized by a HITACHI S-4800 field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a JEOL JEM-2100 instrument. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was conducted using a SHIMADZU XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation. The diffraction patterns were recorded in the 2θ range of 10°–80° with a scan speed of 2°/min. The ultraviolet/visible/near-infrared (UV/VIS/NIR) absorbance spectra were measured with a PerkinElmer Lambda 750 spectrometer. The UC spectra were obtained by Jobin-Yvon iHr550 monochromator and detected with a CR131 photomultiplier tube associated with a lock-in amplifier; the resolution was 0.2 nm and the incident slit was 2.24mm. The luminescence of the samples is imaged by Olympus Microscope DP80. The photocurrent test was conducted using an electrochemical analyzer (CHI 660D, CH Instruments Inc.) with a three-electrode system. The H2 production performance was determined using a gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) (Beifen-Ruili Analytical Instrument, SP-3420A).

sections.heading: 3.1. Structural and compositional characterization
sections.text: Fig. 1 (A) shows that as-synthesized MoO3-x NTs indicates closely arranged slice configuration with the size of 3 μm for each cluster. The Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs exhibit a uniform structure with an average width of 50 nm and thickness of 10 nm (Fig. 1 (B)). The Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH displays a 2D-2D type contact (Fig. 1 (C)). The TEM image indicates that the Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs are created on the surface of the MoO3-x NTs after the solvothermal treatment (Fig. 1 (D)). The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images show the crystal lattices with interplanar distances of ≈0.32 nm and 0.17 nm for the MoO3-x NTs and Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs respectively; these indexed as the lattice spacing of the (021) and (105) facets respectively (Fig. 1 (E, F)). The XRD patterns imply that the ErYb:TiO2 NTs exhibit an anatase structure, which is in accordance with JCPDS 21-1272. The sharp peak confirms that the as-prepared ErYb:TiO2 NTs possess good crystallinity. No RE oxide or chloride peaks are observed, indicating that the RE ions are doped into the TiO2 crystal lattice. The peak of the MoO3-x NTs is in agreement with JCPDS card 5- 0508. The XRD profile of the Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH shows the primary characteristic peaks of both materials, which implies that the ErYb:TiO2 NTs are successfully integrated with the MoO3-x (Fig. 1 (G)). Fig. 1 (H) shows the absorbance spectra of the three samples. The intrinsic absorption edges of Er-Yb:TiO2 and MoO3-x are all located in the UV region. Although Er and Yb ions are doped into the TiO2 crystal lattice, there are no absorption peaks of the elements because of the low doping ratio. MoO3-x exhibits a wide LSPR absorption band covering the visible and NIR regions and Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x exhibits the respective absorption characteristics.

sections.heading: 3.2. UC luminescence characterization
sections.text:
As shown in Fig. 2 (A), the Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs exhibit weak green emissions and strong red emission relative to the energy level transitions 2H11/2, 4S3/2→ 4I15/2 and 4F9/2→ 4I15/2 upon the excitation of a 980 nm laser; this response is attributed to three reasons: 1) the nonradiative energy resonance transfer with a high possibility for the presence of oxide matrix materials; 2) the excited state absorption (ESA) process corresponding to the transition 4I13/2→ 4F9/2 as a result of longer energy level lifetime of 4I13/2, which absorb 980 nm photon to populate on the level 4F9/2; 3) the direct energy transfer (ET) from Yb3+ to Er3+ [23]. The position of the emission band is basically unchanged after the fabrication of the MoO3-x NTs but there is a marked influence on the emission intensity. The Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH exhibits
extremely intense green luminescence and weaker red luminescence. The LSPR absorption band of the MoO3-x NTs is in the NIR region; the excitation and emission fields of the Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs, especially the increased excitation field play a significant role in improving the UCL [2] (Fig. 2 (B)). When the NIR incident frequency matches the vibration of the electrons from the oxygen defects to induce resonance, the NIR photons are concentrated in the local light field and transfer the focused energy to the adjacent Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs; this noble metal-like LSPR effect results in a 182-fold UCL improvement (Fig. 2 (C)). Fig. 2 (D) shows the Ln-Ln plot of the UCL for the Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs and Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH. It is well known that the UCL intensity Iup is proportional to the nth power of the pump power Ppump for the unsaturated UC processes
[24]; this is defined as:
∝I Pup pumpn
where n is the number of photons required to populate the green and red UC emission states. The slopes of the fitted curves for the transitions 2H11/2, 4S3/2→ 4I15/2, and 4F9/2→ 4I15/2 of the Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs and ErYb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH are 1.78, 1.85, 2.35, and 1.72, indicating that the two-photon process is responsible for the UCL of both materials.

sections.heading: 3.3. Photocatalytic properties measurement
sections.text:
Note that the quality of Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs that are grown on the surface of the MoO3-x NTs significantly affects the ultimate H2 production. Fig. 3 (A) shows that Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH samples with different quality (7 mg, 8mg, and 9mg) of Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs are synthesized when hydrolyzing BH3NH3. The optimal amount of Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs is 8mg for the maximum H2 production (≈6.7 μmol/h). Under the excitation of the 980 nm laser (power density≈ 7W/cm2), the H2 yield of the ErYb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH is 1.5 times higher than that of the MoO3-x NTs (Fig. 3 (B)). BH3NH3 has an extremely slow hydrolysis rate without the photocatalyst. For a more intuitive view of the charge transfer process in the Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH, equal proportions of Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs and MoO3-x NTs (≈12:1) are milled together via physical mixing (Fig. 3 (C)). In this case, the mixture sample exhibits approximately the same photocatalytic ability as the MoO3-x NTs. It follows that blending MoO3x NTs and Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs has a negligible influence on the H2 production. In contrast, anchoring small amounts of the Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs on the MoO3-x NTs using a solvothermal method achieves higher H2 yield, which means that the interaction between the Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs and MoO3-x NTs, namely, the carrier transfer process, plays a crucial role in the photocatalytic reaction. The nitrogen adsorption is shown in Fig. 3 (D). With the increase of the specific surface area, the photocatalyst combine more H+ hydrolyzed from BH3NH3 to generate H2. The specific surface area of the Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH (26.11m2/g) is lower than that of the MoO3-x NTs (43.87 m2/g), indicating the interaction between MoO3-x NTs and Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH plays primary role in the photocatalytic reaction, which indirectly proves that the electron transfer process is a major factor in improving the photocatalytic ability. In the photocatalytic procedure, the NIR-driven LSPR effect generates a powerful electromagnetic field, which amplifies the NIR photon energy and improves the UCL of the Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs. In turn, the UC emissions re-excite the LSPR of the MoO3-x NTs that produce “hot electrons” near the surface of the plasmonic semiconductor (∼10 nm) [11,25–31]; a great deal of this is motivated on the high-energy SP state. Despite the generation of a barrier area that prevents the electron transfer process from the MoO3-x NTs to the Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs, the LSPRdriven “hot electrons”, whose energy is higher than that of the barrier area, achieve the electron transfer process. The “hot electrons” pass through the interface of the Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH and are located on the surface of the Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs, where the photocatalytic reaction is achieved (Fig. 3 (E, F)).
In order to obtain a larger solar spectrum utilization rate, simulated sunlight is utilized as an excitation source. Fig. 4 (A) shows the photocurrent test results of the MoO3-x NTs and Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH over time under the irradiation of simulated sunlight. It is observed that the difference between the photocurrent and dark current is larger for the Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH (0.64 μA) than the MoO3-x NTs (0.049 μA), which indicates that the carrier separation for Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH is facilitated. Therefore, the H2 yield of MoO3-x and Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH is further increased due to the simulated sunlight (power density≈ 0.25W/cm2) and the photocatalytic activity for H2 production is 2.5 times for Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x than for the MoO3-x NTs (Fig. 4 (B)). The large absorption range of the MoO3-x NTs enables that LSPR is stimulated more comprehensively. The high concentration of LSPR-driven “hot electrons” leads to a reduction in protons.
To clarify the LSPR influence on the photocatalytic H2 production, the sintered Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH is prepared after annealing at 675 K for 3 h and 24 h. As shown in Fig. 4 (C), no significant morphology changes are observed in the sintered Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH after 3 h (T/M 3) is observed, whereas the LSPR absorption intensity is lower. The sintered Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH that was annealed for 24 h (T/M 24) shows a decentralized sheet structure rather than convergent clusters. The absorption curve becomes flat. To our surprise, the T/M 3 sample displays excellent H2 production performance and the H2 yield is even higher than that of the Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH (Fig. 4 (D)). This is an unexpected result. After the irradiation by simulated sunlight for 1 h, the reactant of T/M 3 turns blue. Therefore, we assume
that a photochromic reaction has occurred. The reaction equation is as follows [32]:
+ + ⇌− + − −MoO yH ye H MoOx y x3 3
The equation indicates that hydrogen molybdenum bronze (HyMoO3-x) is generated by the photochromic reaction. It should be noted that the production of molybdenum bronze has been shown to possess an LSPR effect due to the vacancies, which cause intense NIR absorption and facilitates H2 production [33,34]. Clearly, it is also an LSPR-driven H2 production process. The injection of electrons and the combination of H+ are two requirements for the synthesis of HyMoO3-x. It is conducive that the position of the conductive band of the ErYb:TiO2 NTs is higher than that of the MoO3-x NTs; therefore, the charge transfer process can occur from the Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs to the MoO3-x NTs under the excitation of the UV portion of the simulated sunlight. BH3NH3 provides abundant H+ that participates in the photochromic and photocatalytic reaction. The T/M 3 exhibits excellent photocatalytic properties as a result of the LSPR coupling-driven “hot electrons”, i.e., a dual hot electron transfer process. Similarly, the T/M 24 also results in good H2 production on account of the single LSPR effect because of the lower amount of HyMoO3-x (after the irradiation, the reactant turns light blue).
To confirm the positive effect of LSPR of HyMoO3-x on photocatalytic H2 production, we use visible light as an excitation source, in spite of the fact that the intrinsic absorption of the Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs and MoO3-x NTs is not located in the visible region. As shown in Fig. 4 (E), T/M 3 exhibits higher photocatalytic activity as before under the excitation of visible light (power density is≈ 1W/cm2). Thus, even without the charge transfer process from the Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs to the MoO3-x NTs, LSPR are still observed in the T/M 3 sample, where free electrons are excited to form HyMoO3-x. The high hydrogen production of the T/M 3 sample is equally attributed to the LSPR effect of the HyMoO3-x and the partly passivated MoO3-x NTs; this result is similar to that of the simulated sunlight test, which is shown in Fig. 4 (F). The T/ M 24 sample exhibits relatively poor H2 production performance and the reaction system is not allochroic, which demonstrates that HyMoO3x cannot be synthesized without an electron donor. It is thus evident that HyMoO3-x possesses good photocatalytic properties for decomposing BH3NH3 and the photocatalytic performance of the sample is greatly reduced without the influence of LSPR.
In summary, we created a Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH and investigated the UCL spectrum and photocatalytic H2 production performance. Upon the excitation of a 980 nm laser, the Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH exhibited intense green UCL that was two orders of magnitude higher than that of Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs because of the LSPR of the MoO3-x NTs. Furthermore, when the green emissions interacted with the MoO3-x NTs, “hot electrons” were generated. These high-energy electrons transferred through the interface between the Er-Yb:TiO2 NTs and MoO3-x NTs, which prevented the recombination problem of photo-induced carriers and accelerated the hydrolysis of BH3NH3 to produce H2. The existence of the MoO3-x NTs traps a large proportion of incident light and the wide LSPR absorption band increases the utilization ratio of the sunlight spectrum and the H2 production efficiency under the irradiation of simulated sunlight. The formation of HyMoO3-x through the intervalence charge transfer of Mo ions also improves the H2 production by LSPRcoupling action. The proposed method provides a remarkable strategy for strengthening UCL and improving the wide-spectrum photocatalytic properties for high-efficiency conversion of solar energy to chemical energy.

metadata.abstractText: Localized surface plasmon resonances (LSPR) are widely employed for improving the upconversion luminescence (UCL) and photocatalysis. Here, we prepare a nano-semiconductor heterostructure (NSH) consisting of ErYb:TiO2 nanosheets (NTs) integrated with plasmonic MoO3-x NTs in a two-step solvothermal processes. The LSPR of MoO3-x amplifies and transfers the near-infrared (NIR) energy to the neighboring Er-Yb:TiO2 UC system, leading to a 182-fold increase in green emissions. Moreover, the LSPR effect extends the absorption range of the Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH from the visible to the NIR region. The interface of the Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH acts as a charge carrier channel to separate the plasmon-induced electrons and holes effectively. We perform H2 production experiments of Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH from ammonia borane (BH3NH3). Upon the excitation of a 980 nm laser, the H2 production of the Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH is 1.5 times and 61 times higher than that of the MoO3-x NTs and BH3NH3. In addition, the H2 yield is 2.5 times and 52 times higher than that of the MoO3-x NTs and BH3NH3 under the irradiation of simulated sunlight (AM 1.5), demonstrating the superior photocatalytic properties of the Er-Yb:TiO2/MoO3-x NSH.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
